update.description:
Distortion based on [Brown's model](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distortion_(optics)#Software_correction)

There is a gazebo tutorial [pull request](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/93/camera-distortion-tutorial/diff) documenting how to use this feature. Here is a [link to the tutorial page](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=camera_distortion&branch=camera_distortion)

Depends on sdformat pull request #[120](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/120/add-camera-distortion-element/diff)
update.title: Add simulation of camera distortion

content.raw: Looks like "input" is a reserved word (for future use)  according to [OpenGL ES GLSL](https://www.opengl.org/registry/doc/GLSLangSpec.Full.1.40.05.pdf) section 3.6 keywords. We are using it on this PR GLSL. @iche033 should we change it?
content.html: Looks like "input" is a reserved word (for future use) according to OpenGL ES GLSL section 3.6 keywords. We are using it on this PR GLSL. @iche033 should we change it?

content.raw:
https://gist.github.com/scpeters/723f79a6017935c52d04

There's quite a few errors to sift through there, including the following:
~~~
15:45:15: Cannot compile GLSL high-level shader : Gazebo/CameraDistortionMapFS Fragment shader failed to compile with the following errors:
ERROR: 0:13: error(#133) Reserved word: input
ERROR: 0:13: error(#132) Syntax error: "input" parse error
ERROR: error(#273) 2 compilation errors.  No code generated
~~~

...

content.raw:
Tutorial works on my nvidia-based desktop machine. I noticed that while the Topic Viewer shows distorted images, the CameraVisual that displays in `gzclient` shows undistorted images. This can even be seen in one of your tutorial screenshots:

![tutorial screenshot with undistorted camera image](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/raw/3e939778696c6a34e8a84f025d23801aab1a3a10/camera_distortion/files/distorted_camera_inserted.png)
content.html: Tutorial works on my nvidia-based desktop machine. I noticed that while the Topic Viewer shows distorted images, the CameraVisual that displays in gzclient shows undistorted images. This can even be seen in one of your tutorial screenshots:

content.raw: Should we remove the compositor instance (if present)? (this->dataPtr->lensDistortionInstance)
content.html: Should we remove the compositor instance (if present)? (this->dataPtr->lensDistortionInstance)

content.raw: Perhaps we should link to OpenCV instead of wikipedia?
content.html: Perhaps we should link to OpenCV instead of wikipedia?

content.raw: ditortion <-> distortion
content.html: ditortion <-> distortion

content.raw: Should we log some warning message if this happens for future debugging?
content.html: Should we log some warning message if this happens for future debugging?

content.raw: Also, if we force the value to be negative, should the condition be `>=`?
content.html: Also, if we force the value to be negative, should the condition be >=?

content.raw: I think we don't need this reset().
content.html: I think we don't need this reset().

content.raw: Private data for the Distortion class.
content.html: Private data for the Distortion class.

content.raw: Missing \param for `_center`.
content.html: Missing \param for _center.

content.raw:
Can't believe they [changed the equations](http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Distortion_(optics)&diff=608847847&oldid=606829959). It's a wiki after all. I implemented it a while back based on the old equations. 

I verified the new equations on wikipedia with the ones on OpenCV, they are now consistent. I will update mine.
content.html:
Can't believe they changed the equations. It's a wiki after all. I implemented it a while back based on the old equations.

I verified the new equations on wikipedia with the ones on OpenCV, they are now consistent. I will update mine.

content.raw: Investigating the issue is happening only if I run gazebo using the Intel graphic card. If I enable the nvidia, the result is the modified image expected.
content.html: Investigating the issue is happening only if I run gazebo using the Intel graphic card. If I enable the nvidia, the result is the modified image expected.

content.raw: On the [wikipedia page](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distortion_%28optics%29#Software_correction), the p1's and p2's are reversed in these two equations.
content.html: On the wikipedia page, the p1's and p2's are reversed in these two equations.

content.raw:
I wouldn't mind have the link to background equations here as well:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distortion_%28optics%29#Software_correction
content.html:
I wouldn't mind have the link to background equations here as well:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distortion_%28optics%29#Software_correction

content.raw:
Following the tutorial I'm getting a totally black image on a simple testing scenario. When inserting a standard camera, the result is just fine.

Is it a problem on my end?
content.html:
Following the tutorial I'm getting a totally black image on a simple testing scenario. When inserting a standard camera, the result is just fine.

Is it a problem on my end?

content.raw: The error message is being displayed but ... what the program will keep running. Which will be the final effect on the software of sending k1 < 0?
content.html: The error message is being displayed but ... what the program will keep running. Which will be the final effect on the software of sending k1 < 0?

content.raw: I really love the asserts but in this case looks like SetCamera is a public method, which could be used by an external user. In this case I usually prefer exceptions or error messages instead assertions, which in production code will make the program to exit without any more detail.
content.html: I really love the asserts but in this case looks like SetCamera is a public method, which could be used by an external user. In this case I usually prefer exceptions or error messages instead assertions, which in production code will make the program to exit without any more detail.
